facts.text: Appeals by leave granted by the High Court of Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: These are appeals by leave granted by the High Court of Bombay under article 133 1  c  of the Constitution

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered by JAGANNADH DAS J. on October 11, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: 1954. October 1 1. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by JAGANNADH DAS J.-

facts.text: Bombay Taluqdari Tenure Abolition Act, 1949 was impugned.

anchor.surface_text: The short point involved in these appeals is whether the Bombay Taluqdari Tenure Abolition Act, 1949,  hereinafter referred to as the Act  is valid in law.

facts.text: Act passed by the Bombay Legislature in the year 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The Act, it may be noted, was one passed by the Bombay Legislature in the year 1949.

facts.text: Act received assent of the Governor-General on 18th January 1950.

anchor.surface_text: It received the assent of the Governor-General on the 18th January, 1950, and was gazetted on the 24th January, 1950.

facts.text: Act gazetted on 24th January 1950.

anchor.surface_text: and was gazetted on the 24th January, 1950.

facts.text: Section 3 of the Act abolishes taluqdari tenure with effect from the date the Act comes into force.

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 of the Act enacts that with effect from the date on which the Act was to come into force the taluqdari tenure wherever it prevailed shall be deemed to have been abolished.

facts.text: Under section 5(1)(a) all taluqdari lands are liable to payment of land revenue per Bombay Land Revenue Code.

anchor.surface_text: Under section 5 1  a  all taluqdari lands are and shall be liable to the payment of land revenue in accordance with the provisions of the Bombay Land Revenue Code

facts.text: Under section 6, property comprised in taluqdari vests in Government and rights of taluqdar extinguished.

anchor.surface_text: Under section 6, broadly stated, all the items of property which are comprised within the taluqdari and belong to the taluqdar vest in the Government as its property and all rights held by the taluqdar in such property shall be deemed to have been extinguished.

facts.text: Section 7 provides for payment of compensation for property vested and rights extinguished.

anchor.surface_text: Section 7 provides for payment of compensation in respect of the property so vested and rights so extinguished. It also specifies the principles for and the manner of assessing and granting that compensation.

facts.text: Section 14 provides for compensation per Land Acquisition Act for certain rights.

anchor.surface_text: Section 14 provides for compensation with reference to the provisions of the Land Acquisition Act being payable in respect of any of the rights extinguished but not covered by the provisions of section 7 or any other section of the Act.

facts.text: Attack on Act: it is expropriatory, not for public purpose, compensation illusory.

anchor.surface_text: The attack on the validity of the Act with reference to these provisions is that the Act is expropriatory, that it is not for any public purpose and that the compensation which it provides is illusory.

facts.text: High Court held Act for public purpose and compensation not illusory or unfair, no violation of section 299 GOI Act.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges of the High Court ... dealt with the merits of the challenge and held that the Act was for a public purpose and that the compensation provided was neither illusory nor unfair and that accordingly there was no violation of the provisions of section 299 of the Government of India Act.

facts.text: Act is item 4 in the Ninth Schedule of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: But this Act is one of the Acts specified in the Ninth Schedule of the Constitution being item  4  thereof

facts.text: Bihar Land Reforms Act, 1950 is the first item in the Ninth Schedule.

anchor.surface_text: the validity of the Bihar Land Reforms Act, 1950  Bihar Act XXX of 1950  which is the very first item in the Ninth Schedule

facts.text: Appeals dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals must, therefore, be dismissed with costs.

holdings.text: The abolition of taluqdari tenure of the kind affected by the Act is for a public purpose.

anchor.surface_text: Now so far as the requirement of a public purpose is concerned it is too late in the day to maintain the contention that the abolition of the kind affected by the Act is not for a public purpose.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior precedents establish that abolition of such tenures serves public purpose; too late to contend otherwise.

holdings.text: The Bombay Taluqdari Tenure Abolition Act, 1949 is valid in law as it is protected by Article 31B and inclusion in the Ninth Schedule.

anchor.surface_text: By the above amendment therefore and by specifically enumerating this Act in the Ninth Schedule, it appears to us to have been clearly and unequivocally intended that the provisions of this Act should be immune from attack-of the kind put forward.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit textual application of Article 31B to Acts in Ninth Schedule immunizes from Part III challenges.

holdings.text: Article 31B protects Acts in Ninth Schedule from challenges alleging violation of section 299 of the Government of India Act, 1935.

anchor.surface_text: What article 31-B protects is not a mere contravention of the provisions of Part III of the Constitution but an attack on the grounds that the impugned Act is inconsistent with or takes away or abridges any of the rights conferred by any provisions of this Part.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 299 secures same property rights as Part III; Article 31B targets attacks on such rights, not mere textual contravention; purposive interpretation includes pre-Constitution equivalents.

holdings.text: The right under section 299 of the Government of India Act is equivalent to fundamental rights conferred by Part III of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: One of the rights secured to a person by Part III of the Constitution is a right that his property shall be acquired only for public purposes and under a law authorising such acquisition and providing for compensation which is either fixed by the law itself or regulated by principles specified by the law. That is also the very right which was previously secured to the person under section 299 of the Government of India Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Historical and substantive equivalence; right lifted from legislative fetter to formal fundamental right.

holdings.text: Challenge to Bihar Land Reforms Act under Article 31B was on grounds of fraud on legislative power, not violation of fundamental rights.

anchor.surface_text: A careful perusal of the judgment however shows that the challenge allowed was as to the competency of the Legislature to enact certain provisions of the impugned Act which, in the opinion of the majority of the Court, were in the nature of fraud on the exercise of the legislative power.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent distinction: Bihar invalidity based on legislative competence/fraud, outside Article 31B scope for rights violations.

anchor.surface_text: Now so far as the requirement of a public purpose is concerned it is too late in the day to maintain the contention that the abolition of the kind affected by the Act is not for a public purpose.

We are, therefore, clearly of the opinion that the challenge to the validity of the Bombay Taluqdari Tenure Abolition Act, 1949 on the ground put forward was number open. The appeals must, therefore, be dismissed with companyts.

By the above amendment therefore and by specifically enumerating this Act in the Ninth Schedule, it appears to us to have been clearly and unequivocally intended that the provisions of this Act should be immune from attack-of the kind put forward.

We are, therefore, clearly of the opinion that the challenge to the validity of the Bombay Taluqdari Tenure Abolition Act, 1949 on the ground put forward was number open. The appeals must, therefore, be dismissed with companyts.

What article 31-B protects is not a mere contravention of the provisions of Part III of the Constitution but an attack on the grounds that the impugned Act is inconsistent with or takes away or abridges any of the rights conferred by any provisions of this Part.

We are, therefore, clearly of the opinion that the challenge to the validity of the Bombay Taluqdari Tenure Abolition Act, 1949 on the ground put forward was number open. The appeals must, therefore, be dismissed with companyts.

One of the rights secured to a person by Part III of the Constitution is a right that his property shall be acquired only for public purposes and under a law authorising such acquisition and providing for compensation which is either fixed by the law itself or regulated by principles specified by the law. That is also the very right which was previously secured to the person under section 299 of the Government of India Act.

We are, therefore, clearly of the opinion that the challenge to the validity of the Bombay Taluqdari Tenure Abolition Act, 1949 on the ground put forward was number open. The appeals must, therefore, be dismissed with companyts.

A careful perusal of the judgment however shows that the challenge allowed was as to the competency of the Legislature to enact certain provisions of the impugned Act which, in the opinion of the majority of the Court, were in the nature of fraud on the exercise of the legislative power.

We are, therefore, clearly of the opinion that the challenge to the validity of the Bombay Taluqdari Tenure Abolition Act, 1949 on the ground put forward was number open. The appeals must, therefore, be dismissed with companyts.
